meanings.def: a short thin piece of stiff wire with a sharp point at one end and a round head at the other, used especially for fastening together pieces of cloth when sewing
examples: Use pins to keep the patch in place while you sew it on.

meanings.def: a short thin piece of stiff wire with a sharp point at one end and an item of decoration at the other, worn as jewellery
examples: a diamond pin

meanings.def: a piece of jewellery with a pin on the back of it, that can be fastened to your clothes
a type of badge that is fastened with a pin at the back
examples: He supports the group and wears its pin on his lapel.
an American flag lapel pin

meanings.def: a piece of steel used to support a bone in your body when it has been broken
examples: The pin in her spine will have to be changed as she grows.

meanings.def: one of the metal parts that stick out of an electric plug and fit into a socket
examples: a 2-pin plug

meanings.def: a wooden or plastic object that is like a bottle in shape and that players try to knock down in games such as bowling
a stick with a flag on top of it, placed in a hole so that players can see where they are aiming for
examples: The ball stopped five feet short of the pin.
He’s not as quick on his pins as he used to be.

meanings.def: a small piece of metal on a hand grenade that stops it from exploding and is pulled out just before the hand grenade is thrown
(to be) very anxious or excited while you are waiting to find out something or see what will happen
examples: I've been on pins and needles all week waiting for the results.

meanings.def: used to say that you would like to do something, even though you know that it would not be sensible
examples: I'd kill him for two pins.
For two pins I’d tell her what I really think of her.
The audience was so quiet you could have heard a pin drop.

idioms.def: (to be) very anxious or excited while you are waiting to find out something or see what will happen
examples: I've been on pins and needles all week waiting for the results.

idioms.def: used to say that you would like to do something, even though you know that it would not be sensible
examples: I'd kill him for two pins.
For two pins I’d tell her what I really think of her.

idioms.idiom: you could hear a pin drop
examples: The audience was so quiet you could have heard a pin drop.

meanings.def: to attach something onto another thing or fasten things together with a pin, etc.
examples: She pinned the badge onto her jacket.
A message had been pinned to the noticeboard.
Pin all the pieces of material together.
She always wears her hair pinned back.
I am trying to pin up the hem of this dress.
Maps were pinned to the walls.
She carefully pinned the two pieces of cloth together.
The poster had been pinned onto a large board.
pictures pinned up on the walls
Her hair was pinned up loosely.

meanings.def: to make somebody unable to move by holding them or pressing them against something
examples: They pinned him against a wall and stole his wallet.
He grabbed her arms and pinned them to her sides.
They found him pinned under the wreckage of the car.
He pinned her against the wall.
His arms were pinned behind his back.
She was pinned helplessly to the desk.

meanings.def: to rely on somebody/something completely for success or help
examples: The company is pinning its hopes on the new project.
She did not pin much faith on their chances of success.
He pinned all his hopes on getting that job.

idioms.def: to rely on somebody/something completely for success or help
examples: The company is pinning its hopes on the new project.
She did not pin much faith on their chances of success.
He pinned all his hopes on getting that job.

meanings.def: a number given to you, for example by a bank, so that you can use a plastic card to take out money from a cash machine (the abbreviation for ‘personal identification number’)
